page.title: 18BRANDON HALL
page.content: {Brandon Hall}was originally a rectory. There wasn't a school so the Rector, { {Revd. Teitelbaum}made the upstairs into a school; that was over 100 years ago. A few years ago{Brandon Hall}was abandoned; then about four years ago it was bought and restored, as well as building another house in the front grounds. The back garden has about an acre of land, including a large tennis court.{Brandon Hall}is just up the road from the school. In {1938}a new teacher from the new school visited{ {Brandon Hall.}This is how she described it:- the house had tall iron gates and a drive covered with moss. The door was open, revealing a spotless stone floor. It had oil lamps and a bookcase down one side.The brass brightly shone in the sun. There was a large{Victorian Dining-room}which had a table big enough for twelve people.
